CountryData.name: Cocos (Keeling) Islands
CountryData.description: The Cocos (Keeling) Islands are a remote and idyllic group of coral atolls located approximately 1400 km north of Perth, Western Australia.  Forming part of the Australian External Territories, these islands boast stunning beaches, vibrant coral reefs, and a unique ecosystem shaped by centuries of isolation.  The islands are a haven for birdlife and offer a tranquil escape for those seeking untouched natural beauty and a glimpse into a simpler way of life.

quickFacts.label: Official Name
quickFacts.description: The islands are administered by the Australian Government.
quickFacts.detail: They are part of the Australian External Territories.

quickFacts.label: Area
quickFacts.detail: Comprising two main islands, West and East Cocos.

quickFacts.label: Population
quickFacts.detail: Mostly comprised of lighthouse keepers, support staff, and their families.

quickFacts.label: Currency
quickFacts.description: The islands use the Australian currency.
quickFacts.detail: Transactions are primarily conducted through mail services.

quickFacts.label: Time Zone
quickFacts.description: Located in the Australian Western Standard Time zone.
quickFacts.detail: A significant time difference from most of the world.

climateData.title: Tropical Climate
climateData.description: The Cocos (Keeling) Islands experience a tropical maritime climate characterized by consistently high temperatures and humidity throughout the year. Rainfall is generally moderate, with distinct wet and dry seasons.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Summer (December - February)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Summer brings the hottest temperatures and heaviest rainfall.  The humidity is consistently high.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Autumn (March - May)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Autumn sees a gradual decrease in rainfall and temperatures. The sea remains warm, making it ideal for water activities.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Winter (June - August)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Winter is the coolest and driest time of year.  Temperatures are still pleasant, and the skies are often clear.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Spring (September - November)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Spring brings a return to warmer temperatures and increasing rainfall. The islands come alive with new growth.

naturalWonders.name: Cocos Solo Atoll
naturalWonders.description: Cocos Solo is the largest and most prominent atoll of the Keeling Islands, renowned for its exceptional biodiversity and pristine coral reefs. It’s a vital breeding ground for numerous marine species and a stunning example of a tropical ecosystem.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The atoll features a lagoon surrounded by a ring of coral reefs, offering incredible snorkeling and diving opportunities. The surrounding islands provide nesting sites for seabirds and a haven for diverse flora and fauna.

naturalWonders.name: West Cocos Island
naturalWonders.description: West Cocos Island is the larger of the two main islands, dominated by a dense coconut palm forest and offering a glimpse into the islands’ unique history and ecology.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The island’s interior is rugged and hilly, providing habitat for a variety of bird species. The lighthouse on West Cocos is a significant landmark and a vital aid to navigation.

ecosystemData.title: Unique Atoll Ecosystem
ecosystemData.overview: The Cocos (Keeling) Islands represent a remarkably isolated and fragile ecosystem, shaped by millennia of geological processes and limited human impact. The atolls are home to a diverse range of marine and terrestrial life, many of which are found nowhere else on Earth.

biodiversityCategories.description: The surrounding coral reefs teem with a vast array of marine life, including colorful fish, sea turtles, sharks, and rays.

statistics.details: Diverse coral communities support a complex food web.
A significant number of endemic fish species.

biodiversityCategories.name: Birdlife
biodiversityCategories.description: The islands are a crucial nesting site for numerous seabird species, including terns, frigatebirds, and shearwaters.

statistics.details: Important breeding grounds for migratory birds.
Protected nesting areas are vital for bird survival.

notableSpecies.name: Red-tailed Tropicbird

notableSpecies.name: Masked Booby
